sources.data_found: ECU's Office of Research has purchased a 3-node cluster totaling 192 CPU cores and 1,280 GB of RAM in NC State's HPC core facility. N-Series systems optimized for GPU workloads including NVIDIA Tesla P40, M60, or V100 GPUs.
Total Enrollment 26,940 ECU Students. STEM/Health Care Enrollment 42% of Total Student Body 8,598 Undergraduate 2,821 Graduate.

In 2023, the most popular Bachelors Degree concentrations at East Carolina University were Registered Nursing (351 degrees awarded), General Business Administration & Management (311 degrees), and Public Health Education & Promotion (261 degrees). There were 26,785 students enrolled at East Carolina University in 2023.
Of the 104 students who earned a bachelor's degree in Computer & Information Sciences from ECU in 2021-2022, 89% were men and 11% were women.

student_data.notes: Based on 104 CS bachelor's degrees awarded in 2021-2022 and typical 4-year program duration, estimated undergraduate CS enrollment is ~250-260. Graduate CS count estimated from typical MS enrollment patterns. PhD count not found - ECU CS department does not appear to offer a PhD program.

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: ECU has access to Azure N-Series systems with M60 GPUs through Microsoft Azure HPC pilot program. Exact count not specified.

gpu_resources.notes: ECU has limited GPU resources through two pilot programs: 1) Microsoft Azure cloud access with N-Series systems including P40, M60, or V100 GPUs (consumption-based, no specific counts), and 2) NC State HPC Partner Program access through Hazel cluster. ECU owns a 3-node CPU cluster at NC State but GPU access appears to be through shared queue time. Estimated 3-6 total GPUs accessible between V100, P40, and M60 models.

analysis_notes: ECU has very limited GPU infrastructure. Primary HPC access is through partnerships - a pilot program with Microsoft Azure (consumption-based cloud GPUs) and owned compute nodes at NC State's Hazel cluster (CPU-focused with shared GPU queue access). The university does not appear to operate its own on-campus GPU cluster.
